results.title: Fire making
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
A Pintubi boy makes a fire by friction of a spear-thrower on a log.

results.title: A Family moves camp and gathers food
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Filmed in May 1965 in the Desert Sandhill country of the Western Desert, the film documents a group of Aboriginal families still living their traditional way of life. Shows them moving camp, hunting and gathering.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Cooking kangaroo
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
A Pintubi man prepares and cooks a red kangaroo and divides it among his family. (Some scenes may offend animal rights supporters).

results.title: At Patantja clay pan
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Daily activities of two families camped near a clay pan holding water, showing desert food resources in a good season. The men hunt emus and the women collect mulga seed, ngaru fruit and grubs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.description:

results.title: People of Many Lands

group_works.title: Arab traders of the Persian Gulf
group_works.creator_credit: Peggie Broadhead and British Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Arab traders of the Persian Gulf
results.creator_credit: Peggie Broadhead and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People of Many Lands”.
A journey across the barren desert areas of the Gulf of Arabia with Arab traders. These are nomadic people living in primitive conditions. The film is one of a series which deals with a wide range of people, some of whom have retained primitive ways of life and have little contact with the outside world.
results.description:

group_works.title: An Equal opportunity
group_works.creator_credit: Caroline Leaf, Robert Verrall, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

group_works.title: A Right to refuse?
group_works.creator_credit: Clayton Bailey, Caroline Leaf, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: An Equal opportunity
results.creator_credit: Caroline Leaf, Robert Verrall, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People at Work”.
This open-ended drama is designed to trigger discussion on the subject of equal opportunities for women in the workplace and on the role of unions in securing those opportunities and working to eliminate discriminatory labour practices. Though set within a hospital and focussing on one of several staff women who are denied access to a pharmacy training program despite suitable qualifications, the underlying premises, conflicts and responses have implications that reach far beyond the hospital walls. Written by Gynne Basen, Clayton Bailey, Caroline Leaf; photographed by Wolf Koenig; edited by Judith Merritt; sound by John Martin, Bernie Bordeleau
results.creator_credit_for_label: Caroline Leaf, Robert Verrall, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: A Right to refuse?
results.creator_credit: Clayton Bailey, Caroline Leaf, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People at Work”.
Dramatization of an industrial conflict. Workers should realise that they have the right to refuse to do jobs under dangerous or unhealthy conditions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Clayton Bailey, Caroline Leaf, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
